facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1950 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1950.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 17th March 1944 of Patna High Court in F.A. No. 47 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a judgment and decree dated 17th March, 1944, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Fazl Ali J. and Beevor J.

facts.text: Arising out of decree dated 27th February 1942 of Subordinate Judge of Purnea in Title Mortgage Suit No. 7 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: in F.A. No. 47 of 1942, arising out of decree dated 27th February, 1942, of the Subordinate Judge of Purnea in Title Mortgage Suit No. 7 of 1940.

facts.text: Appeal originally taken to Judicial Committee on special leave granted by Order in Council dated August 2 1946, transferred to Supreme Court due to abolition of Privy Council jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, which was originally taken to the JudicialCommittee, on special leave, granted by an Order in Council dated August 2, 1946, number stands transferred to this companyrt by reason of the aboli- tion of the jurisdiction of the Privy Council.

facts.text: Suit commenced by plaintiffs respondents for enforcement of simple mortgage bond by sale of mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before us are the first party defendants in a suit, companymenced by the plaintiffs respondents, for enforcement of a simple mortgage bond, by sale of the mort- gaged property.

facts.text: Trial Judge held bond not legally attested, refused mortgage decree, passed money decree personally against first party defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge, while deciding all the other issues in favour of the plaintiffs, held on the evi- dence on the record, that the bond sued upon was number legally attested and hence companyld number rank as a mortgage bond. On this finding he refused to make a decree for sale

facts.text: Suit instituted more than 6 years after due date but personal claim not time-barred due to payments attracting section 20 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Subor- dinate Judge, although the suit was instituted more than 6 years after the date fixed for payment in the bond, yet the claim for personal relief against the mortgagors did number become time-barred by reason of the fact that there were several payments

facts.text: Defendants mortgagors appealed to Patna High Court, no appeal or cross-objection by plaintiffs against refusal of sale decree.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision an appeal was taken by the defendants mortgagors to the High Court of Patna, but numberappeal or ,cross-objection was filed by the plaintiffs against the refusal of the trial Court to make an order for sale of the mortgaged property

facts.text: Patna High Court held bond duly attested, effective as mortgage, suit within time, affirmed money decree as no appeal by plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on hearing the appeal came to the companyclusion that the bond in suit was duly attested and was effective and enforceable as a mortgage bond, and that the view taken by the trial companyrt on the question of attestation companyld number be sustained

facts.text: Mortgage bond dated 8th April 1927.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage bond is dated the 8th of April, 1927, but it is numberlonger disputed that the executants put their signatures to the document on the 12th of April fol- lowing

facts.text: Executants signed mortgage bond on 12th April 1927, registered on same date.

anchor.surface_text: , but it is numberlonger disputed that the executants put their signatures to the document on the 12th of April fol- lowing, and admittedly it was registered on the latter date.

facts.text: Due date in mortgage 6th March 1928.

anchor.surface_text: The due date, as given in the mortgage, is the 6th of March, 1928.

facts.text: Suit instituted on 4th March 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted on 4th of March, 1940,

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed eight payments totaling Rs. 780-9-0: Rs300 on 21 Jan 1928, Rs75 on 5 Jun 1929, 8 Mar 1931, 3 Apr 1931, May 1932 (two), 25 Jul 1934, 15 May 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs stated specifically in their plaint that the defendants made eight payments in all, aggregating to a sum of Rs. 780-9-0, in part satisfaction of the debt, since the execution of the mortgage bond. The first payment which was of a sum of Rs. 300 was made on 21st January, 1928, and this was before the expiry of the due date mentioned in the bond. The second payment was of Rs. 75 and was made on the 5th of June, 1929. The third payment is dated 8th of March, 193l, and the fourth was made within one month after that on 3rd April, 1931. the fifth and the sixth payments were both made in the month of May, 1932, the seventh on 25th July, 1934, and the last payment was made on 15th of May, 1936.

facts.text: Defendants 1 to 3 admitted payments in paragraph 15 of written statement.

anchor.surface_text: What the Subordinate Judge relied upon, is the admission companytained in paragraph 15 of the written statement filed on behalf of defendants 1 to 3 in the present suit where these defendants admitted number only that the payments specified in the plaint were actually made on the respective dates

facts.text: No endorsements of payments on bond itself, no signed acknowledgment by debtors prior to suit.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly in the case before us, numbere of the payments specified above were endorsed on the bond itself and there was numberacknowledgment either in the handwriting of, or signed by, the debtors prior to the institution of the suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court held payments do not extend limitation as no written acknowledgment in plaint at filing time.

anchor.surface_text: the suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the companyrts below companysequently were number justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.

facts.text: Mortgage bond written at plaintiffs house in village Chakla Maulanagur on 21st Chaitra 1334 Fasli corresponding to 8th April 1927.

anchor.surface_text: the evidence shows that the mortgage bond was written and engrossed at the plaintiffs house at village Chakla Maulanagur and the date which the document bears is 21st Chaitra 1334 Fasli companyresponding to 8th April, 1027.

facts.text: Attesting witnesses: Sunderlal, Matukdhari Prasad, Dwarka Prasad, Nanak Prasad (scribe), all residents of Chakla Maulanagur.

anchor.surface_text: There are four attesting witnesses whose names appear in the deed, to wit, Sunderlal, Matukdhari Prasad, Dwarka Prasad and Nanak Prasad the last named person being also the scribe of the document --and all of them were residents of Chakla Maulanagur which is the place of resi- dence of the mortgagees.

facts.text: Mortgagors inhabitants of village Chandpur.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagors, on the other hand, are inhabitants of a different village, namely, Chand- pur.

facts.text: Sunderlal (PW1) stated signed bond at plaintiffs house same day written and attested.

anchor.surface_text: Sunderlal, who is P.W. 1, states when cross-examined on behalf of some of the defendants I signed the bond at the plaintiffs house, as did the attesting witnesses. The attestation of the bond was on the same day that it was written.

facts.text: Matukdhari Prasad stated bond written, signed by executants and attested by witnesses on same date.

anchor.surface_text: The other attesting witness, Matukdhari Prasad, during cross-examination said as follows The bond was written, signed by the executants and attested by the wit- nesses on the same date.

facts.text: Executants signatures dated 12th April 1927, presented for registration at Katihar same day.

anchor.surface_text: The document shows that all the three executants put their signatures to it on 12th of April, 1927, and on the same day it was presented for registration before the Regis- tering Officer at Katihar.

facts.text: Supreme Court found attestation defective as witnesses signed before execution on 12th April.

anchor.surface_text: As the document was written on the 8th but actually executed on the 12th, the Subordinate Judge was of opinion that the attesting witnesses must have signed the deed before it was executed land this was numberattestation in the eye of law.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 Sant Lall stated signatures at Katihar, not plaintiffs village.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked as to whether the document was executed at the plaintiffs village or at Katihar, where it was taken for registration. The witness persisted in saying that he and the other executants put their signatures number at the place of the plaintiffs but at Katihar

issues.text: Whether the suit for personal decree is barred by limitation or saved by part payments under section 20 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: This leads us to enquire as to whether the trial Judge was right in holding that the payments made by the defendants satisfied the requirements of section 20 of the Indian Limitation Act and were hence available to the plaintiffs for the purpose of extending the period of limitation within which the suit should otherwise have been brought.

issues.text: The short point for our consideration is whether the view taken by the Subordinate Judge is correct? [re: written statement as signed acknowledgment under section 20 proviso]

anchor.surface_text: The short point for our consideration is whether the view taken by the Subordinate Judge is correct ? It would be clear, we think, from the language of section 20 of the Limitation Act that to attract its operation two conditions are essential first, the payment must be made within the prescribed period of limitation and secondly, it must be acknowledged by some form of writing either in the handwriting of the payer himself or signed by him.

issues.text: Whether even if the bond is a mortgage bond, no decree for money could be passed against the defendants personally unless within Article 116 Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. De, who appeared in support of the appeal, has contended in the first place that even if the High Court was right in holding that the bond in suit was effective as a mortgage bond and the suit could be treated as one for enforcement of a mortgage, no decree for money could be passed against the defendants personally, unless the suit was instituted within the period prescribed by Article 116 of the Limitation Act.

issues.text: Whether the finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case

anchor.surface_text: To decide this question there are two points which require consideration -- Whether the finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case ? If it is so, whether the facts of the plaintiffs not having preferred an appeal or cross-objection

anchor.surface_text: Whether the finding of the High Court on the question of attestation is a correct and proper finding on the evidence adduced in this case ? If it is so, whether the facts of the plaintiffs not having preferred an appeal or cross-objection against that part of the judgment of the trial Judge which refused them a mortgage decree, stands in the way of their claiming any relief other than what was given to them by the trial Judge ?

holdings.text: The suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the courts below consequently were not justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.

anchor.surface_text: the suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the companyrts below companysequently were number justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No written signed acknowledgment of payments existed prior to suit institution; limitation assessed at plaint filing date per s3 Limitation Act and O7 R6 CPC; written statement admission post-dates suit.

holdings.text: It is essential that such acknowledgment, whether made before or after the period of limitation, must be in existence prior to the institution of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: But while it is number necessary that the written acknowl- edgment should be made prior to the expiry of the period of limitation, it is, in our opinion, essential that such acknowledgment, whether made before or after the period of limitation, must be in existence prior to the institution of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s20 requires payment proved by pre-existing written acknowledgment signed by payer; post-suit written statement does not qualify; aligns with policy excluding oral proof.

holdings.text: The Subordinate Judge is right in holding that while the section requires that the payment should be made within the period of limitation, it does not require that the acknowledgment should also be made within that period.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, however, is right in holding that while the. section re- quires that the payment should be made within the period of limitation, it does number require that the acknowledgment should also be made within that period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s20 does not import words requiring acknowledgment within limitation period; supported by High Court precedents.

holdings.text: If the bond in the present case cannot be treated as a mortgage bond and the only relief which the plaintiffs can claim is one for recovery of money against the defendants personally, the suit must be deemed to be barred, as it was instituted beyond 6 years from the due date of payment unless limitation is saved by reason of the payments under section 20 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: This leads us to enquire as to whether the trial Judge was right in holding that the payments made by the defendants satisfied the requirements of section 20 of the Indian Limitation Act and were hence available to the plaintiffs for the purpose of extending the period of limitation within which the suit should otherwise have been brought.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registered bond for personal recovery governed by Art 116 (6 years); framing as mortgage does not extend personal remedy limitation.

anchor.surface_text: But while it is number necessary that the written acknowl- edgment should be made prior to the expiry of the period of limitation, it is, in our opinion, essential that such acknowledgment, whether made before or after the period of limitation, must be in existence prior to the institution of the suit.

This being the position, the suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the courts below consequently were not justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.

anchor.surface_text: This leads us to enquire as to whether the trial Judge was right in holding that the payments made by the defendants satisfied the requirements of section 20 of the Indian Limitation Act and were hence available to the plaintiffs for the purpose of extending the period of limitation within which the suit should otherwise have been brought.

This being the position, the suit treated as one for obtaining a money decree against the defendants must be held to be barred by limitation at the date on which it was instituted and the courts below consequently were not justified in giving the plaintiffs a money decree in this suit.
